events.description: Seleucus I Nicator captures Babylon from Antigonus's forces after Battle of Gaza; this date marks the official founding of the Seleucid Empire and became Year 1 of the Seleucid Era calendar used for centuries across the Near East
events.name: Foundation of Seleucid Empire

events.description: Seleucus I founds Seleucia on the Tigris as his eastern capital, north of ancient Babylon; the city becomes one of the largest in the ancient world with population reaching 600,000, serving as administrative center for Mesopotamia
events.name: Foundation of Seleucia on the Tigris

events.description: Seleucid-Mauryan War concludes; Seleucus I cedes territories east of the Indus River (including Arachosia, Gedrosia, Paropamisadae) to Chandragupta Maurya in exchange for 500 war elephants and a marriage alliance - these elephants prove decisive at Battle of Ipsus
events.name: Seleucid-Mauryan Peace Treaty

events.description: Battle of Ipsus in Phrygia; coalition of Seleucus I, Lysimachus, and Cassander defeats Antigonus I Monophthalmus who is killed in battle. Seleucus gains control of Syria and eastern Anatolia, dramatically expanding his empire westward
events.name: Battle of Ipsus

events.description: Seleucus I founds Antioch on the Orontes River, naming it after his father Antiochus; the city becomes the western capital and eventually the primary seat of Seleucid power, growing into one of the greatest cities of antiquity
events.name: Foundation of Antioch

events.description: Seleucus I establishes the Syrian Tetrapolis - four sister cities: Antioch (capital), Seleucia Pieria (port), Apamea (military base named after his wife Apama), and Laodicea (named after his mother) - forming the administrative core of western Seleucid lands
events.name: Syrian Tetrapolis Established

events.description: Seleucus I Nicator assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus while crossing into Europe to claim Macedonia; the founder of the Seleucid dynasty dies just months after his greatest victory, never reaching his ancestral homeland
events.name: Assassination of Seleucus I

events.description: Battle of Corupedium in Lydia; Seleucus I defeats and kills Lysimachus, the last of Alexander's original successors. The Seleucid Empire reaches its greatest territorial extent, stretching from Thrace to the borders of India
events.name: Battle of Corupedium

events.description: Antiochus I Soter, son of Seleucus, leads the empire together with Stratonice, his former stepmother.
events.name: Reign of Antiochus I Soter Begins

events.description: Antiochus I defeats Galatian Celts in the 'Elephant Victory' - war elephants inherited from Indian campaigns terrorize Celtic warriors who had never seen such beasts, ending their threat to Greek cities of Asia Minor. For his victory in the battle, Antiochus received the nickname 'Soter' (Savior)
events.name: Elephant Victory over Galatians

events.description: First Syrian War begins between Seleucids and Ptolemaic Egypt; Ptolemy II Philadelphus attacks Seleucid territories, exploiting succession troubles. This initiates a century-long series of conflicts over Coele-Syria (Palestine and southern Syria)
events.name: First Syrian War Begins

events.description: First Syrian War ends with Ptolemaic victory; Egypt gains control of Phoenician coast, parts of southern Anatolia, and the Cyclades Islands. Seleucids lose access to important Mediterranean ports
events.name: First Syrian War Ends

events.description: Antiochus II Theos becomes king after his father's death; he earns the epithet 'Theos' (God) from Miletus for liberating them from tyranny. His reign sees partial recovery in the Second Syrian War
events.name: Reign of Antiochus II Theos

events.description: Second Syrian War begins; Antiochus II with Macedonian support attacks Ptolemaic holdings. The war results in Seleucid recovery of Phoenicia and coastal Anatolia
events.name: Second Syrian War

events.description: Peace treaty ends Second Syrian War; Antiochus II divorces his wife Laodice to marry Ptolemy II's daughter Berenice Syra. This fateful decision plants seeds for the devastating Laodicean War and future civil strife
events.name: Seleucid-Ptolemaic Marriage Alliance

events.description: Diodotus I declares independence of Bactria from Seleucid rule, founding the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom; this marks the beginning of major territorial losses in the eastern satrapies that would never be fully recovered
events.name: Bactrian Independence

events.description: Arsaces I leads the Parni nomads to conquer Parthia, founding the Arsacid dynasty; this begins the rise of the Parthian Empire that would eventually destroy Seleucid power in the east and become Rome's great rival
events.name: Foundation of Parthian Empire

events.description: Third Syrian War (Laodicean War) begins; Ptolemy III Euergetes invades to avenge his sister Berenice's murder, penetrating deep into Seleucid territory and briefly reaching Babylon - the furthest east any Ptolemaic army would ever march
events.name: Third Syrian War (Laodicean War)

events.description: Antiochus's ex-wife, Laodice, seizes power in Asia Minor and promotes her son, Seleucus II, to the throne. On Laodice's orders, Berenice of the Ptolemies and her son are killed.
events.name: Laodice seizes Seleucid empire

events.description: Antiochus II Theos dies under mysterious circumstances, possibly poisoned by his first wife Laodice; the succession dispute between Laodice's son Seleucus II and Berenice's infant son triggers the Third Syrian War
events.name: Death of Antiochus II

events.description: Third Syrian War ends; Seleucus II retains his throne but loses northern Syrian coast cities and territory in southern Anatolia. The empire is severely weakened and faces internal challenges
events.name: End of Third Syrian War

events.description: War of the Brothers erupts; Antiochus Hierax rebels against his brother Seleucus II, claiming the Anatolian territories for himself. This civil war further weakens Seleucid power and allows external enemies to expand
events.name: War of the Brothers

events.description: Antiochus III 'the Great' becomes king at age 18 after his brother Seleucus III is assassinated; he inherits a shrunken, troubled empire but will prove the most capable Seleucid ruler since the founder
events.name: Reign of Antiochus III the Great

events.description: Antiochus III suppresses the rebellion of Molon, satrap of Media, who had declared himself king; this early victory demonstrates the young king's military competence and begins the restoration of central authority
events.name: Suppression of Molon's Revolt

events.description: Fourth Syrian War begins; Antiochus III invades Coele-Syria, achieving initial successes against Ptolemaic forces. The young king seeks to recover territories lost to Egypt over previous decades
events.name: Fourth Syrian War Begins

events.description: Battle of Raphia in Gaza; Ptolemy IV Philopator defeats Antiochus III's larger army using newly trained native Egyptian phalanx - the first time Egyptians fought as hoplites. This ends Antiochus's first attempt to conquer Coele-Syria
events.name: Battle of Raphia

events.description: Antiochus III begins his great eastern campaign (Anabasis), marching to restore Seleucid authority over breakaway eastern satrapies; the expedition will last eight years and cover thousands of miles
events.name: Eastern Campaign of Antiochus III Begins

events.description: Antiochus III defeats Parthian King Arsaces II and captures Hecatompylus; Parthia is forced into vassalage, acknowledging Seleucid suzerainty. The king pursues retreating Parthians across difficult mountain terrain
events.name: Reconquest of Parthia

events.description: Battle of the Arius River; Antiochus III surprises and defeats Bactrian cavalry of Euthydemus I through a daring night march, demonstrating tactical brilliance. He then besieges the fortress city of Bactra
events.name: Battle of the Arius River

events.description: Peace with Bactria; after lengthy siege of Bactra, Antiochus III negotiates with Euthydemus, allowing him to retain his throne in exchange for nominal vassalage and a marriage alliance. Euthydemus supplies war elephants for future campaigns
events.name: Seleucid-Bactrian Peace

events.description: Antiochus III crosses the Hindu Kush into India, renewing alliance with King Sophagasenus and receiving 150 war elephants; following in Alexander's footsteps, he extends Seleucid influence to the furthest east since the founder
events.name: Antiochus III in India

events.description: Antiochus III returns triumphantly from eastern campaign, earning the title 'the Great' (Megas); he has restored Seleucid authority from Armenia to India, though many vassals will soon reassert independence
events.name: Antiochus III Earns Title 'the Great'

events.description: Fifth Syrian War begins; Antiochus III and Philip V of Macedon secretly agree to partition Ptolemaic possessions after death of Ptolemy IV leaves infant Ptolemy V on the throne under weak regents
events.name: Fifth Syrian War Begins

events.description: Battle of Panium near the source of the Jordan River; Antiochus III decisively defeats Ptolemaic forces led by Scopas. This victory permanently transfers control of Coele-Syria (Palestine) from Ptolemaic to Seleucid rule
events.name: Battle of Panium

events.description: Antiochus III completes conquest of Coele-Syria; Jerusalem and Judea pass from Ptolemaic to Seleucid control. The Jewish population initially welcomes the Seleucids, who grant them religious privileges
events.name: Seleucid Control of Judea

events.description: Antiochus III invades Greece at invitation of Aetolian League, landing with only 10,000 infantry and 500 cavalry; he fatally underestimates Roman power, believing Greeks would flock to his banner as liberator
events.name: Antiochus III Invades Greece

events.description: Battle of Thermopylae; Romans under Manius Acilius Glabrio decisively defeat Antiochus III at the famous pass. The Seleucid king is forced to evacuate Greece entirely and retreat to Asia Minor
events.name: Battle of Thermopylae (191 BC)

events.description: Battle of Magnesia near Smyrna; Roman and Pergamene forces under Scipio Asiaticus crush Antiochus III's army of 70,000 in the decisive battle of the war. Seleucid power west of the Taurus Mountains is destroyed forever
events.name: Battle of Magnesia

events.description: Treaty of Apamea imposes crushing terms on Antiochus III: cede all territories west of Taurus Mountains, pay 15,000 talents indemnity over 12 years, surrender war elephants and navy, and hand over enemies of Rome including Hannibal
events.name: Treaty of Apamea

events.description: Antiochus III killed while plundering a temple of Bel in Elymais to raise funds for war indemnity; the once-great king dies ignominiously, ending an era of Seleucid revival that ultimately failed against Rome
events.name: Death of Antiochus III

events.description: Antiochus IV Epiphanes becomes king after his brother Seleucus IV is assassinated; having spent years as hostage in Rome, he understands Roman power but his aggressive Hellenization policies will provoke the Maccabean revolt
events.name: Reign of Antiochus IV Epiphanes

events.description: Sixth Syrian War begins; Antiochus IV invades Egypt, defeating Ptolemaic forces and capturing young Ptolemy VI. He comes close to conquering all Egypt, the first Seleucid to do so since the empire's founding
events.name: Sixth Syrian War - Invasion of Egypt

events.description: Eleusis Day. The army of the legate Gaius Popillius Laenas surrounded the army of Antiochus IV near Alexandria. Laenas draws a circle in the sand around Antiochus and demands that Antiochus decide to retreat from Egypt before leaving the circle. Antiochus suffers humiliation at the hands of the Romans and leaves Egypt with his army.
events.name: Day of Eleusis

events.description: Antiochus IV desecrates the Jerusalem Temple, erecting altar to Zeus Olympios and banning Jewish religious practices including circumcision and Sabbath observance; this 'Abomination of Desolation' triggers the Maccabean Revolt
events.name: Desecration of Jerusalem Temple

events.description: Maccabean Revolt begins; Judas Maccabeus leads Jewish rebellion against Seleucid religious persecution. The guerrilla campaign in Judean hills will eventually lead to Jewish independence
events.name: Maccabean Revolt Begins

events.description: Battle of Beth Horon; Judas Maccabeus ambushes and defeats Seleucid army under Seron in mountain pass, proving that disciplined guerrilla tactics could overcome Hellenistic professional armies
events.name: Battle of Beth Horon

events.description: Judas Maccabeus recaptures and purifies the Jerusalem Temple exactly three years after its desecration; the Hanukkah festival commemorates this rededication and the miracle of oil lasting eight days
events.name: Rededication of Jerusalem Temple (Hanukkah)

events.description: Antiochus IV Epiphanes dies during eastern campaign, possibly from illness or grief over Jewish revolt; his death triggers succession crisis and accelerates Seleucid decline
events.name: Death of Antiochus IV Epiphanes

events.description: Battle of Elasa; Judas Maccabeus killed fighting against Seleucid general Bacchides. Despite his death, the Jewish revolt continues under his brothers Jonathan and Simon
events.name: Death of Judas Maccabeus

events.description: Mithridates I of Parthia begins conquest of eastern Seleucid territories; over the next decade he will seize Media, Persia, Elymais, Characene, and eventually Mesopotamia, permanently ending Seleucid presence in the east
events.name: Parthian Conquest of Eastern Seleucid Lands

events.description: Simon Maccabeus achieves de facto Jewish independence; Seleucids formally recognize Jewish autonomy and exempt Judea from tribute. The Hasmonean dynasty is established
events.name: Jewish Independence Achieved

events.description: Parthians capture Seleucia on the Tigris, the eastern Seleucid capital; all territories east of the Euphrates are lost permanently. The empire is now confined to Syria and parts of Cilicia
events.name: Parthians Capture Seleucia

events.description: Demetrius II Nicator captured by Parthians while attempting to recover eastern territories; he will spend 10 years in Parthian captivity, married to Parthian princess Rhodogune
events.name: Demetrius II Captured by Parthians

events.description: Antiochus VII Sidetes launches ambitious campaign to recover Mesopotamia and eastern provinces from Parthia; initially successful, he reconquers Babylonia, Media, and briefly restores Seleucid power east of the Euphrates
events.name: Eastern Campaign of Antiochus VII

events.description: Battle of Ecbatana; Parthians under Phraates II defeat and kill Antiochus VII Sidetes, the last great Seleucid king. This battle ends any hope of recovering the eastern territories and marks the final collapse of Seleucid power
events.name: Battle of Ecbatana - Death of Antiochus VII

events.description: Seleucid Empire reduced to rump state; decades of civil wars between rival claimants have reduced the once-mighty empire to little more than Antioch and a few Syrian cities, plagued by constant dynastic conflicts
events.name: Seleucid Empire as Rump State

events.description: Tigranes II the Great of Armenia conquers Syria, virtually ending Seleucid independence; the Armenian king rules over former Seleucid lands as part of his vast empire stretching from the Caspian to the Mediterranean
events.name: Armenian Conquest of Syria

events.description: Rome defeats Tigranes and Mithridates VI of Pontus; rump Seleucid kingdom briefly restored under Antiochus XIII, but the remnant state is plagued by civil wars with rival claimant Philip II
events.name: Brief Seleucid Restoration

events.description: Pompey the Great annexes Syria as a Roman province, formally ending the Seleucid Empire after 249 years; the last Seleucid claimants are deposed. Antioch becomes capital of the new province of Syria
events.name: Roman Annexation of Syria - End of Seleucid Empire
